terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colorado mountains. Massive elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional CO ultra event. Massive mountain terrain with remote location, high altitude, and small regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Pony Xpress Gravel 160 is a regional ultra event in Colorado—massive mountain terrain with extreme elevation and high altitude. The 160-mile distance and Colorado mountains are epic, but the small regional field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional CO ultra gravel race. Worth it for ultra/CO riders. Not worth traveling far for unless you're chasing ultra challenges.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to CO and chasing ultra challenges—yes. If you're traveling—skip it unless you're ultra-focused.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better CO ultra races: Check regional ultra options.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Trinidad has limited lodging. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Trinidad has limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.signature_challenge: 160-mile ultra distance with 12000 feet of elevation at high altitude.

non_negotiables.why: 160-mile ultra distance requires extensive ultra training.
12000 feet of elevation requires sustained mountain effort.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional ultra event with massive mountain terrain and high altitude.

logistics.explanation: Tony Huston traveled from Houston with zero acclimatization and "no real idea of what to expect," highlighting the minimal pre-race information available. Sunday packet pickup ending at 8:30 AM for a 9 AM start creates dangerous time pressure, and the complete absence of parking, lodging, or travel details forces participants to figure out Trinidad logistics on their own.

length.explanation: Three aid stations at miles 25, 50, and 75 support the full 160K distance with proper fueling infrastructure. The course delivers a 20-mile climb to 8,800 feet that had Tony Huston "telling each other that we weren't crying, there was just mountain dust in our eyes." Two laps of the 85K course means experiencing every major climb twice, creating sustained suffering over the full distance. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: The course combines 96% gravel county roads with technical navigation challenges requiring GPS and handlebar-mounted maps. One 160-mile rider got lost multiple times following a malfunctioning Garmin, and limited course markings in remote areas with no cell reception create real navigation risk. Tony Huston described the gravel as "fine gravel roads, perfect for light tires" on the technical terrain. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: 12,000 feet of gain over 160K puts this firmly in the hurt-locker category - that's 75 feet per kilometer of pure vertical punishment. Rolling foothills in the Sangre de Cristo range means constant up-and-down rather than one massive climb, which can be more devastating over distance. The elevation profile alone makes this a sufferfest regardless of the race's other shortcomings. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Tony Huston puts it: "Then began the most formidable portion of the PX 160—the long, 20-mile climb up to 8,800 feet."

climate.explanation: The 2025 race got postponed from April 19 to May 4 due to "inclement weather," which tells you spring conditions in southern Colorado are unreliable at best. May weather in the mountain foothills can range from perfect to miserable with little warning. Organizers had to move the entire event suggests they're still figuring out optimal timing for this location. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Trinidad sits around 6,000 feet with the course climbing into higher foothills, putting you in moderate altitude territory that affects sea-level dwellers but isn't devastating. It's enough to notice if you're coming from lower elevations but not high enough to require serious acclimatization. The rolling terrain means you're constantly changing elevation, which can amplify the altitude impact over 160K. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Riding through historic mining areas including the Ludlow Memorial adds historical context to the suffering. Starting in Cokedale and climbing through Sangre de Cristo foothills with Fisher Peak views delivers mountain adventure. The Pony Express theme isn't just marketing fluff - you're actually traversing historic frontier territory that adds meaning to the miles. As Remote Course Conditions puts it: "Areas of the course are very remote with limited mobile phone reception. It will be very important that all riders monitor there energy levels, weather conditions and navigational tools."

prestige.explanation: A race so invisible that no past winners are mentioned anywhere and results are buried on racetecresults.com tells you everything about its standing. Being the Colorado State Gravel Championship venue sounds impressive until you realize nobody talks about it and the entire 2026 season is "paused." The gravel community has spoken with silence.

race_quality.explanation: Organizer Phil was described as "incredibly relieved and happy when the last riders came through, giving bro-hugs at the final aid station," suggesting grassroots organization rather than professional race management. The 10 MPH minimum pace requirement for 160K creates real cutoff pressure, but multiple riders getting lost due to limited course markings reveals execution gaps in a remote, challenging environment.

experience.explanation: Starting in Cokedale and riding through historic mining areas including the Ludlow Memorial should create memorable moments, but the execution falls short. Fisher Peak views and Sangre de Cristo mountain backdrop provide scenic payoff, but packet pickup ending at 8:30 AM for a 9 AM start is cutting it dangerously close. The bones of a good experience exist but aren't properly developed.

community.explanation: A race that bills itself as reigniting "your passion for cycling" but generates no passionate testimonials is telling you something. 2026 is paused suggests even the organizers aren't that committed to building something lasting.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-200 riders, no field size data, no notable past winners, no pro participation mentioned despite being a state championship venue. When a race can't even generate enough buzz to produce publicly available results or rider stories, the competitive depth is clearly minimal. The separate pro start times suggest they're trying to create elite racing, but where are the elite racers? Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Entry fees ranging from $89.95 early bird to $149.95 late registration buy access to spectacular Colorado mountain terrain with three well-stocked aid stations featuring Hammer Nutrition products. However, the intimate 15-rider field and basic finish line amenities (t-shirts only) provide limited race experience for the premium pricing, especially given the navigation risks in remote terrain.

expenses.explanation: Trinidad offers affordable lodging options including Las Animas County fairgrounds camping at $25 per night with basic amenities. The course is described as "fine gravel roads, perfect for light tires," keeping equipment costs reasonable, and the remote southern Colorado location away from resort areas helps control accommodation expenses for visiting riders. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

unsplash_photos.description: a group of people riding motorcycles down a street

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Bite
primary.why: Technical terrain dominator. Aggressive grip when the course gets rowdy.

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel S
primary.why: Soft-terrain specialist. Open knob pattern sheds mud and grips wet rock.

videos.title: Pony Xpress 160 85k Gravel Cycling Race 2019
videos.description:
PX160 85k route. May 18th 2019. Cokedale, CO.

Music by Arch Echo - You Won't Believe What Happens Next!
Song 1: Aurora (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgvyGpV0whw)
Song 2: Tempest (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UR0SWD0S398)
videos.curation_reason: Longest duration ride-along video showing actual race footage from the 85k route.

videos.title: Spinistry Trinidad Mule Train Gravel Adventure
videos.description:
The Spinistry hosted a gravel bicycle adventure on the roads around Trinidad, Colorado on July 6th, 2019.

The ride held up to the name as all of the riders were caught in a torrential thunderstorm at around 7,500' of elevation.

All riders came out unscathed and smiling with quite the story to tell their friends and family back home.

videos.title: 2021 Pony Xpress 85km
videos.description:
2021 Pony Xpress 85k on May 8, 2021, hosted just outside Trinidad, CO in the small town of Cokedale. Personally, this was the first competitive anything I've done in close to 5 years, and after 11 months off the bike last year I was happy to finish in under 3:30 (3:12:55!). I made up a lot of time on the descents, got crushed on the climbs (usual story). Incredible scenery, mining ruins, beautiful gravel made for an incredible day. COS Racing had a successful day out, taking the entire men's podium in the 85k and 1st on the women's podium.

Ridden on a 2021 Giant Revolt Advanced 0 with Teravail Cannonball 42s.

videos.curation_reason: Detailed first-person race experience of the bikepacking category with good production quality and transcript available.

quotes.text: It's gonna be hot high 90s 100 both days so that'll make it interesting... I had a big old shard of glass tore through my rear tire and realized that my frame pump is not on my frame.
It's nice to know everybody's looking out for each other out here which is half the reason it's so nice to enjoy some time riding bikes together.

key_challenges.name: Glass on course
key_challenges.description: Big shard of glass tore through rear tire around mile 40. Roads haven't been too rough but glass hazards present.

key_challenges.name: Stream crossings
key_challenges.description: Multiple stream crossings along the course on maintenance roads.

key_challenges.name: Heat and headwinds
key_challenges.description: High 90s to 100 degree temperatures both days with headwinds developing later in the day, creating suffer fest conditions.

terrain_notes.text: Smooth saddling so far, smooth roads with tailwinds early. Lots of minimum maintenance roads. Some climbing involved with steep climbs.
First part of day is enjoyable before it gets hot, with tailwinds when everyone's fresh.

race_day_tips.text: It's gonna be hot high 90s 100 both days, so take it easy on day one if doing the two-day bikepacking format.
Make sure your frame pump is actually on your frame - don't be that guy having to rely on others.
Stay with front group early while it's nice and cool in the morning, trying to keep grit down and make time before conditions deteriorate.
Gas stations in small towns along route have water and orange juice for resupply.

additional_quotes.text: It's nice to know everybody's looking out for each other out here, which is half the reason it's so nice enjoy some time riding bikes together. Neil was kind enough to ride a mile back down one of the steeper climbs of the day to help me out.

rider_intel.search_text: The Pony Express Gravel features smooth roads early with tailwinds, transitioning to challenging conditions with high 90s to 100 degree temperatures both days. Course includes lots of minimum maintenance roads, stream crossings, and steep climbs. Glass hazards present - one rider suffered tire damage from glass shard around mile 40. Route passes through small towns with gas stations for water and supply resupply. Early morning conditions are pleasant before heat and headwinds develop, creating suffer fest conditions later. Strong community spirit among riders helping each other with mechanical issues. Beautiful rural churches and scenery along the route. Two-day bikepacking option available with camping midway through.
